The "Protecting Young Victims from Sexual Abuse and Safe Sport Authorization Act of 2017" includes required reporting of child and sexual abuse, civil remedy for personal injuries, expansion of the purposes of the corporation, designation of the United States Center for Safe Sport, additional requirements for granting sanctions for amateur athletic competitions, and general requirements for youth-serving amateur sports organizations. Required reporting of child and sexual abuse is mandated by an amendment to the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990. Covered individuals must report suspected abuse to the designated agency promptly. The curr_chunk defines terms related to covered individuals in amateur sports organizations, including the definition of a covered individual and the terms related to events and amateur athletes. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to covered individuals in amateur sports organizations, including the meaning of amateur athlete, amateur athletic competition, and national governing body. It also clarifies that "as soon as possible" means within a 24-hour period. Section 2255 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow minors who were victims of specified violations to sue for personal injury in any US District Court. Section 2255 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow minors who were victims of specified violations to sue for damages in any US District Court. The lawsuit can be filed within 10 years of discovering the violation or injury, or within 10 years after the victim reaches 18 years of age. The court may award actual damages, liquidated damages of $150,000, attorney's fees, punitive damages, and other relief as deemed appropriate. The amendment allows actions under subsection (a) to be brought in a US district court meeting venue requirements. Process can be served in any district where the defendant is an inhabitant or can be found. TITLE II--UNITED STATES CENTER FOR SAFE SPORT AUTHORIZATION

SEC. 201. EXPANSION OF THE PURPOSES OF THE CORPORATION. Amends Section 220503 of title 36, United States Code to include promoting a safe environment in sports free from abuse of any amateur athlete.

SEC. 202. DESIGNATION OF THE UNITED STATES CENTER FOR SAFE SPORT. Adds a new subchapter III to Chapter 2205 of title 36, United States Code for the United States Center for Safe Sport. The United States Center for Safe Sport is designated to serve as the national organization for safeguarding amateur athletes against abuse in sports, including emotional, physical, and sexual abuse. It will develop training and policies to prevent abuse in amateur athletic activities. The United States Center for Safe Sport is responsible for responding to and resolving allegations of sexual abuse in sports through established mechanisms that ensure fair notice, opportunity to be heard, and protect complainants' privacy and safety. The Center may utilize arbitration to resolve such allegations within its jurisdiction. The United States Center for Safe Sport resolves allegations of sexual abuse within its jurisdiction, ensuring the opportunity for individuals accused to participate in athletic competitions. The Center does not affect individuals' rights to pursue civil remedies for personal injuries resulting from abuse. Additionally, the Center limits liability for damages, except in specific circumstances. The applicable entity is not liable for damages in defamation cases related to their responsibilities. This exemption does not apply if the entity acted with malice or outside their designated functions. Applicable entities include the Center, national governing bodies, paralympic sports organizations, and sanctioned amateur sports organizations. The Center, national governing bodies, paralympic sports organizations, and sanctioned amateur sports organizations are exempt from liability in defamation cases related to their responsibilities, unless they acted with malice or outside their designated functions. The Center is tasked with developing training and policies to prevent abuse of amateur athletes. The Center, national governing bodies, and paralympic sports organizations must report any suspicion of child abuse of a minor athlete to the Center and law enforcement. A mechanism approved by a child abuse expert allows easy reporting of incidents. The procedures outlined include reporting child abuse suspicions to appropriate authorities, limiting one-on-one interactions between minors and adults, prohibiting retaliation against reporters, and implementing oversight procedures through audits by independent experts. The audits by independent subject matter experts ensure policies are followed correctly and consistent training is provided to adult members in contact with minor athletes. Additionally, there is a mechanism for reporting suspected child abuse confidentially within national governing bodies and sports organizations. The section outlines the procedures for reporting and handling allegations of child abuse involving minor athletes, including sharing information with relevant organizations and withholding interaction authority for adults accused of abuse until resolution. The Center for Safe Sport must maintain accurate records and submit an annual report to Congress, including an audit and a summary of its activities. Additionally, the definition of 'Center' and 'child abuse' are clarified in the legal amendments. The legal amendments clarify the definition of 'child abuse' as given in the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990. Additional requirements for granting sanctions for amateur athletic competitions include implementing policies to prevent abuse of amateur athletes. SEC. 204. General requirements for youth-serving amateur sports organizations. SEC. 204. General requirements for youth-serving amateur sports organizations include compliance with reporting requirements, limiting one-on-one interactions between minor athletes and adults, and providing consistent training to all adults involved. SEC. 204 requires youth-serving amateur sports organizations to provide training on child abuse prevention, allow easy reporting of incidents, and prohibit retaliation against individuals who report abuse. The term 'applicable amateur sports organization' refers to those participating in interstate or international competitions with adult members in regular contact with minors. Amendment requires youth-serving sports organizations to provide child abuse prevention training and allow easy reporting of incidents.
